job_title: Anonymous Employee in Thief River Falls, MN
pros: Good pay. Some good benefits but very very restrictive for health coverage and options. Good pickup incentives and compensation for mandate pay and working extra. Once you’ve proven yourself (which you shouldn’t have to do to get basic respect however), very nice team of LPNs and RNs that help each other out. Great OB team of nurses.
cons:
Little prioritization of patient care and evidenced based care and practice, which includes the push to simplify other responsibilities in order to increase the time spent at bedside. The more time spent at bedside by nurses the better patient outcomes, lower rate of readmissions and complications, and significantly less occurrence of medical errors, falls, and safety issues BUT NO ON CARES ABOUT THIS. Charting and other meaningless tasks are so heavily incentivized, excessive, and prioritized over all the else by management and the nurses. Minimal time to actually care for patients and give them the time they deserve, and no one really cares or is bothered by that. Very inefficient in that aspect and with charting. 

Training in actually kinda sucked. Really  a ton of fear and bullying between coworkers with minimal respect or mentoring by staff. Really fear-based run, and staff are scared to reach out to management or stand up for themselves. Advocating for nurses themselves and for patients/patient care minimally done and most are scared to speak up or out, the few that actually care. 

A lot of the this is how we do it so just put your head down and do it. Not a lot of innovation or drive to be better.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Fargo, ND
pros:
• Coworkers work together to create a great team
• Some physicians are the heart of the company, willing to teach and go the extra-mile to be able to make patients feel at home, amazing CT surgeons and locums
• Rapid Response Team very helpful in situations, prompt
• Lower Management is supportive
cons:
• Cardiac Tele treated like Med/Surg, fresh open hearts sometimes after 12 hours in the ICU
• Pay is horrible, not fairly compensated even for cost of living. Pay increases 3-5% with a measly bonus of $300-$600 end of year, and don't forget the turkey/ham/fruit platter gift card 
• Job well-done by management was usually a gift card for coffee, 
• Management and Directors have no real say in the company, had three managers within several years of working there
• RNs and PCTs treated like second-rate employees, staff ratios sometimes 6:1 with charge having two patients on Cardiac Tele, short-staffed
• Rapid Response Team was overworked, sometimes multiple rapids going on at the same time
• Forced overtime several times within several years
• High turnover which means not many seasoned nurses
• Management is very top-heavy, managers managing managers scenario
• ICU overworked, sometimes ratios were 3:1, due to this Cardiac Tele took unstable patients or we had a rapid before and ICU said patient should remain on floor
• No true career advancement unless you want to work there for years and years with low pay, even lower management does not get paid well especially for the work that they do
• When transferring from PCT to nurse, I was denied a $15,000 bonus, because it was a shift in position even though terms didn't state for new hires only
• Starting pay was low (several years ago about $25, current 2022 is about $31)
• Salary caps are low even though they just increased it to about $43 for RNs

job_title: Associate Sterile Processing Technician in Fargo, ND
pros: The work is generally always abundant and OT is generally always an option. The evening, overnight, and or weekend pay premiums are beneficial. The variety of tasks helps keep the job interesting and engaging. Usually food service staff will deliver snacks (2-qt ish bowls with apples, chips, bars) intermittently throughout a day, however this may be limited with stressed staffing levels. During high-populations weeks, there will commonly be a free meal served (typically on a Wednesday).
cons:
Workplace stress is high. Many of the fellow co-workers are openly spiteful about working conditions and do not comment to avoid conflict (And wait their time out if near retirement age). Contacting HR or any other workplace service contact is frustrating as most offices are located from Sioux Falls and are staffed with individuals that do not care to humanize or relate to clinicians, or anyone outside of their metropolitan area. Overall balance of workplace duties is hard to manage and some tasks end up being overwhelmed both in workload and physical endurance. Training is treated like a burden rather than a duty and the department continues to use brand new employees to churn out more newly trained employees. This sense of rush is especially escalated with Tech IIs or IIIs, where lower managers are pushing seasoned employees to take a duty raise, for the mgmt purpose of being able to allocate more duties to freshly promoted techs. There is no standard of quality control through the training process (outside of IAHCSMM certification acquired within 2 years of hire) and there currently is no "training the trainer". Within this area, there are a lot of encounters with adjacent OR staff, and when issues occur, it can take far longer to communicate across all micro-departments, due to the separation . This division was especially problematic during the time of COVID, both in rationing of PPE and unsafe/improper use of PPE (once no longer in short-supply). Similarly, there are still struggles with purchasing acceptable PPE for decontamination staff, as many weeks during 2021 resulted in boot-covers being used as replacements for impermeable bouffant head-covers. The building conditions at the Broadway OR/SPD are both depressing and deteriorating. Two ORs had to be fumigated for bugs during my time, and the remaining 11 rooms were in various states of cleanliness, often with OR staff leaving unused opened sterile gloves or wrappings in in-room storage to try to repurpose for the next service. The SPD department is also languishing with an assembly area missing 30% of computers, repeated water damage to the ceiling tiles due to roof leaks, poor air ventilation, frequent leaks to plumbing, and air-ventilation systems are caked with dust. Additionally, the scrubs distributed through the hospital side of the facility widely vary in quality and size availability and there were many weeks my size would be mispackaged in the scrub vending machine, or the set was in such poor condition, I could have shredded my set if I overstretched or mis-stepped. There were little to few resources available to avoid ergonomic-related injuries. A few examples of helpful resources we could have used include: adjustable height monitors for all work-place PCs, kneepads for any in-depth cleaning or major organization, adjustable standing desk (particularly for the dispensing window), more seating and stools that included back support. 
Lastly, I was frustrated and distraught to learn that due to lack of staff, the majority of my initial training was conducted with a team member who refused to be vaccinated for COVID-19, despite my prior concerns to my supervisor that I was taking this position largely to seek COVID precautions and safeguards in my workplace. Upon learning this individual was anti-vax weeks after(through their public outburst) I felt discounted and silenced about my concerns to management.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Scientist in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Sanford offered a slightly higher starting wage than Avera did.
cons: Working at Sanford was an unbelievable nightmare. They intentionally left us understaffed to extent that we were unable to take breaks but then they would reprimand us if we failed to take our 1 hour unpaid lunch. The unspoken expectation was that we were to commit time card fraud and to work off the clock, which I did for the first 6 months until I realized it had become literally an every day event. When I stopped clocking out because we were too busy to take a lunch my supervisor started calling and ordering me to clock out for lunch, so I did and went to lunch but then I was written up for "leaving the lab unattended" during the lunch break I was ordered to take. When I finally complained to HR they told me "that is just how healthcare is and you knew what you were getting into." After complaining to HR my supervisor became increasingly more hostile and angrier and she started using half truths to fabricate reasons to write me up. For example, the nurses came in a threw a bunch of covid samples on the counter while I was drawing a patient so my supervisor wrote me up for "leaving the lab messy and in disarray." I scheduled a few meetings with HR to argue my case but again they blamed me and argued "we all must make sacrifices". I heard after I left that management stopped pressuring people to work off the clock as much. I imagine they were afraid of a lawsuit and rightfully so. Still, if you value your dignity or have a strong moral compass then I would stay far away from this company.

job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: There are some really great people who are inspired to make a difference for patients, but unfortunately this is not the current vision of the Sanford IT leadership.   My experience is that many people show up to do what is required to get them out the door.   Leadership has provided no true leadership other than to state we want to be a 20 billion dollar company and then work to protect their own jobs   Revenues are a laudable goal but they don't harmonize with what they pay their employees with many only getting 1% cost of living increase.
cons:
Poor leadership which comes from a fear and insecure based management style.   The CIO says one thing in group meetings to all employees and then berates his reports for doing that same thing (courage, audacity, standing up) in meetings with him.   Leadership leads from an authentic place and people understand the mission and vision by what is carried forth by those leaders. 
The vision and mission from Sanford Executives is do what you need to do to get to the next level and look out for yourself.

There are leaders that will knowingly let your clinic run short staffed  and compromise patient safety and satisfaction because you wont "drink the Kool aide". Threats, manipulation, lying, and covering for employees that have been at Sanford 10 plus years and are completely unproductive are part of the normal leadership pattern. It is one of the most pathetic leadership systems. Common sense and hard work really have NO place at Sanford. Compliance and turning your back to what is right are acceptable and rewarded. One leader was turned in to HR multiple times by his management team for various infractions and Sanford promoted him! Don't believe the hype, Sanford is swimming with incompetence and it starts with the leadership that doesn't even house themselves at the hospital! Their culture and values do not exist, but you will find a considerable amount of laziness and apathy for doing the right thing.

review_title: Academic Research Run like a Corporation
job_title: Laboratory Technician in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Sanford Research has amassed an impressive amount of talent and built an incredible facility in Sioux Falls, South Dakota.  Each lab is largely able to run as an independent operation under the Sanford Research umbrella.  This allows a lot of flexibility in scheduling,  as well as some great mentoring opportunities
cons: Senior leadership leaves much to be desired.  It isn't hard to see there is a large case of nepotism where many promotions and positions are created for people from one specific lab family tree.  As a technician, do not expect a serious raise until you have worked here for 5-7 years or have a strong track record of publications (This changes if the lab you join has external funding sources).

job_title: Ancillary Service in Fargo, ND
pros: There are many wonderful front line workers in this place.  I enjoy my working relationships with many “salt of the Earth” kind of people.  Many of the buildings are new and well kept.  Great opportunity to interface with and care for patients.
cons: The “Sanford Family” rhetoric comes down from administration.  Upper administration does not care about your human needs.  People are promoted into management who are not real leaders but puppets who use cheerleader talk and manipulation to use you up and burn you out.  The business model feels very inhumane and administration pretends to listen to front line workers, but it is only showmanship.  Good company to work for if you need to be ordered around but bad company to work for if you want a manager who values and responds to your needs.

job_title: Clinical Informatics Specialist in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: They paid for my certifications.  Friendly and helpful co-workers.  No micro-management.  You can leave campus for lunch.  Decent technology to work on.
cons: Management is not knowledgeable about the system.  You are constantly explaining the same thing day in and day out.  Some co-workers do not know how to use the system after years of working with it.  They are stuck in the box, will not listen to ideas from outside.  Management will keep dumping work on you unless you complain.  They will promise help and not hire unless you quit.  Unfair treatment of employees.  Management won't care unless they are forced by their boss.

job_title: Staff RN in Fargo, ND
pros: Lots of resources for staff RN. Rescue RN to help with the IVs and PICC dressings. Supplies for the unit are well stocked. Great hospital to work and learn from. Lots of incentive shifts if you want to work overtime. Hook ups to discounts at local restaurants and businesses. Lots of opportunities for advancement. Staff are friendly and promote a culture of teamwork. 4% 401k matching, cheap health insurance.
cons: $23.80 base pay with 1-6% annual salary increase per year is low, even when compared to neighboring hospitals. Not all units are not well staffed due to high turnover. This means you might be down a CNA or two at times. You have to stay 2 years for the 401k or they take it away.

review_title: Sanford bought out Meritcare - wish they had stayed in South Dakota
job_title: Physician in Bemidji, MN
pros: The reasons to work here are the same reasons that it was good to work for Meritcare. The people here are still good. Patients are wonderful.  Lots of dedicated, hard-working nurses and physicians.
cons: The farther away management is from day-to-day activities, the worse the decisions are. Pension plan eliminated for physicians.  Health benefits have been cut (!). New, more complicated billing method for patients. And uncompensated, mandated training for a new software program?  All while Sanford launches money at every sports venue they can to get their name up on the buildings.  2 Million here for the City of Bemidji to name the new hockey arena after the company.  Whoopie.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: You get paid. Work environment can be good if your boss doesn't micromanage.
cons:
Low pay. Health insurance too expensive (considering that insurance premiums go into Sanford provider network, they do not leave Sanford money system). Bad corporate culture.

Regular employees are expendable, skills and experience have no value; voicing concerns does no good, you're told to "go work at Avera". 

Supervisors/managers have no decision power; most things are decided at a director level and above. And yet, no one at the top level takes any responsibility for the disarray they create. There's no accountability (how many in leadership got fired over the "mistake" that cost $20 million?)

Ever since money started falling from the sky (thanks Denny), leadership's modus operandi is to protect each other and enjoy healthy compensation packages. It's a club of untouchables who can do no wrong. 

So, departments are mismanaged, employees are stressed out, overworked and underpaid, turnover is very high, skilled employees leave (wonder why you see so many young faces?) and patient care is at its worst (just ask around).

If Sanford were a regular, for-profit business, it'd be bankrupt by now.

review_title: A lot of room to grow
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Fargo, ND
pros: Small team, friendly people, good benefits (PTO - 23 days a year is pretty average, 6% 401k match, a nice contribution to your HSA if you choose the high deductible plan)
cons: The research department in Fargo really needs to find a way to better balance their hiring strategy vs. their strategy of taking on new studies. There seems to be large swings in workload, ie, months of down time and then months of panicked over-worked stress. In addition, I think the Fargo clinical research team is underresourced in comparision to Sioux Falls. I also don't see a clear path upward as far as getting promoted and recognized for your work (becoming a  "Senior" clinical research coordinator, for example. This position just opens once in a while and only one person can get it).

review_title: An okay place to work if you don't want to advance professionally
job_title: in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Staff is respectable, hours are reasonable, there are perks for volunteering your time towards a non-profit organization. Senior management communicates through email.
cons: Health insurance is extremely expensive, and copays can be high. There is also little to no chance for advancement unless you are a nurse. I have been trying to contact human resources for a month about chances for job advancement when I receive my bachelor's degree, with no response. It seems that the only way you can really be appreciated here is if you are a nurse, at least the system dedicates an entire year to you. Other people in other job roles are left by the wayside.

review_title: Pay not competitive especially with cost of living increasing.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fargo, ND

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fargo, ND

Sanford gives away millions of dollars to make themselves look good, but the money came at the expense of the employees healthcare insurance. An employer of Sanford will have to pay a minimum of $175 just to be seen in the ER. That doesn't include lab work, x-rays, or medication.  If you have another option for a place to work don't choose Sanford!

review_title: It's their way or the highway

review_title: Nice people in state-of-the-art medical facilities that truly care about patients

cons: Very bureaucratic, lots of big organizational changes that surprised everyone, although it was no surprise that there were lots of reorganizations.

job_title: Staff RN in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Good coworkers and enjoyed the flexibility of self scheduling.  Always plenty of job openings in every department if you like to changes specialties and mix it up.

Raises were given based off peer review and other factors not really specified.  For the most part everyone in your job class gets the same percent raise regardless of performance.

review_title: True family feel - it's not just a slogan!

You can make a large company like Sanford feel small, but you can't make a small company feel/act big.
cons: Sanford's a large organization, it's hard to keep up with all the work being done in every location/state.

job_title: Office Assistant, Scheduler, Then Registrar in Fargo, ND

job_title: Respiratory Therapist in Sioux Falls, SD

Must work a 4 hour 7pm-11pm shift every two weeks. Managers do not take complaints of staff seriously. New hires are paid close to or more than those who have been there for years.

review_title: WAS a good place to work....

They sit on facebook and do non work related things instead of helping on the floor.  The health insurance is horrible.  The coverage they offer is bad.  The wages are not comparable to aide work in the nursing homes around the area and you do just as much work if not more.

review_title: I loved working here!  The people were so wonderful and helpful, and I learned so much as its a teaching hospital!

review_title: Good Employees but Growing too fast
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fargo, ND
pros: Sanford Health has opportunities to transfer to different areas.  The training offered via Learning Management System and additional training is nice.
cons: There are alot of concerns with upper management.  Staff shortages, employee retention and employee recognition are a few of the key struggles a growing company goes through.  There is definitely a sense of employee's being replaceable.  The extensive growth, especially in Fargo region combined with limited resources makes it hard to attract good employees.  Company has a bad reputation in the community.  Compensation and Benefits package is POOR for a Health system.

job_title: CNA in Fargo, ND
pros: Good benefits and a nice facility .
cons: The pay is awful for the type of work you do. This hospital will pretty much hire anyone with a pulse as a nurse aid. Some aids are truly great, but many more are incompetent and won't do their share of work, leaving it for those who actually care to pick up the slack. Don't bother raising concerns to your manager about other employees failing to do their jobs, ignoring polies, or repeatedly no call-no showing/being late either. Absolutely nothing will get done to remedy any of it. Sanford is by far the most frustrating place I have ever worked and I would recommend any aid to stay far, far away from there unless you you don't care about doing your job and have zero accountability.

review_title: Great opportunity from ground up. So many great people.

cons: Sanford is growing at such a rapid rate that at times they over load the front line management while not always giving the support needed to keep from burn-out.

review_title: Sanford was my first place of work after graduating from nursing school. I worked there for 5 years.
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Fargo, ND

cons: One problem that I encountered was the parking availability for employees. If you could find a spot on campus it was very crowded and if not you had to drive to a farther location and take a shuttle which can be difficult to coordinate with your schedule.

job_title: Senior Drug Testing Coordinator in Bismarck, ND
pros: Sanford has excellent benefits, especially the insurance. The amount of PTO that accrues is also a plus. After working for Sanford for 5 years, employees receive 3 weeks of PTO and counting. Sanford Health has a lot of room for career growth and promotion. The company culture is positive and empowering.
cons: Sanford is often short-handed, so employees have high work loads. Sanford also has a strict budget, making departmental needs and overtime hard to acquire. This has also contributed to a high turnover.

job_title: Technician in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Some people are good I'm sure but I met everyone with their noses up in the air. Come back down to earth people, your NOT that great!!!
cons:
Sanford cares about Sanford. Not employees or patients. All "employee managers" are let go and then nazi managers come in one department at a time and tell you to be honest and your job is completely safe. Lies!!! 
Advice to employees... Never tell the truth if you want your job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bismarck, ND
pros: From what I have seen, some employees try very hard to make sure patients don't get lost in the system. Customer service is detailed and complete.
cons: As a Nurse, I have never seen such disrespectful treatment of CNAs by nursing staff. It is like the nurses believe their assistants are butlers for them and not patient care technicians for the patients. They have lost their entire CNA staff three times because of a bullying problem that has yet to be addressed successfully. Some of the nurses run things on a fifth grade political system and if you have too much integrity to buy into it, you become a target as well, whether you are a nurse or a CNA. The nurses sit in clumps of six individuals and gossip about things unrelated to work for hours at a time while the CNAs run circles around them cleaning and caring for patients and yet a brief work-related collaborative discussion between CNAs is broken up and scattered like a slave revolt. It seriously impacts patient care, especially combined with the common dispersion of casual racism that is a frequent topic of discussion. The wages are so low that they do not pay enough for a single person to afford the cost of living in this region and the benefits require you to receive your care from the same staff you work with each day. No thank you! You think this crew will not betray HIPA laws to gossip about your medical history  in the break room when you come in to have your appendix out? Think again.

job_title: Applications Administrator in Sioux Falls, SD
pros:
Sanford utilizes their workforce, so there's a sense of job security and you'll be comfortable knowing you won't be let go as long as you perform.

Internal movement options, you can change roles easily if you find something else you want to do within the organization.

The sense of community among your peers is pretty solid.  My fellow employees are what's keeping me coming back to this job day after day.  Cheers to them.

You work for a healthcare organization, so what you do helps people in some way.
cons:
Raises have been poor for IT, specifically (clinical staff get the bulk of the raises that "raise the average" that is reported yearly, it feels like IT gets the leftovers),  for the past few years.  Salaries for many IT positions are on the lower side of being competitive from what I've seen across MN and more specialized IT businesses in the area...

The IT department and, consequently, the organization as a whole lack internal cohesion and direction.  It feels like Sanford Health IT and Sanford Health are separate organizations at times.  This causes a lot of miscommunication and bumping heads in planning projects. review_title: Horrible work experience, Horrible manager. Run from this place!
job_title: Research Associate in Fargo, ND
pros: I was able to advance throughout my career. Small town, short drive.
cons:
We got a new boss, same age as me but with a giant inferiority complex and the perfect mix of a right to work state (ND). It started when I was told I was not to be looking up HR/employee policies, that I just need to accept what the managers said is  policy, and DON"T question it. The manager was lying and contradicting HR written policy and would get angry when caught in a lie. After that meeting I knew I was not going to last very long.

Shortly afterward came the attempts at isolation from the work pod. The boss would get in little digs when she could, publicly pointing out how she hated my laugh, etc. The straw that broke her back though was when I caught her trying to remove information from a patient's electronic medical record so the patient would then qualify for a research study (ignoring the risk of drug interactions). She then quickly acted on my termination which happened about 1 week later.

The worst though was the one office sheep, who I considered a good friend (several times we went to movies, golfed, dinners, etc). The boss specifically told my friend of her plan to fire me and my friend was directed to write down every possible thing I did 'wrong', like leaving for break from a door not located next to the bosses office (Really HR...really?). The "friend" complied and 90% of what she wrote was complete lies that never even happened and the rest was colorfully embellished or ridiculously mundane, like the above "door insubordination". HR did nothing to investigate if any of it was true; HR's only role is to protect the manager and protect the business. I had double digit years of stellar reviews from 5 different departments, including my last review which was approx 60 days before I was fired.

I found out this plan because the "friend" is unable to keep a secret to save her life. A different office mate transferred out a few months after I, who then felt safe filling me in on the details on how the "friend" told the office mate that there was a plan in place to "document" events to ensure a few of us were fired, and that my "friend" was specifically asked to be instrumental in providing the boss with this false documentation. All apparently with HR's blessing (because if someone wrote it down it was then considered true and not hearsay). 

Here is a tip, if you file with the EEOC, after your case is closed you can request a full copy of your personnel file. I knew my case would get nowhere in a right to work state, but I did get a copy of my entire work & EEOC file and I was able to read word for word the lies my "friend" wrote. 

All in all, getting fired was the best thing that ever happened to me.  I relocated, was hired at a 20% pay increase compared to the salary I was making when fired and the retirement fund I was forced to cash in to live on has nearly doubled at my new employer. All annual reviews are same as my previous employer - stellar. Shortly after relocating my personal life also changed for the better as well. I can't say the same for the boss. Her life played out publicly in the news with some horrible karma - which I did not really believe in until I read what happened to her and the likes of which I would never wish on anyone!

Years later, the only one thing that still stings a little - the gal who I thought was a friend turned out to be such an evil person. I do miss the friend I thought she was, but I do not miss the person she truly is.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: The frontline staff are extremely dedicated people who really care about others.  They work their fingers to the bone for this place.
cons: Sanford as a whole cares little for their employees and would prefer to employ robots.  Money is now the main focus and "expanding their footprint" so the CEO can leave his legacy.  You want proof Sanford is really slipping?  In the latest annual "Best of" Issue in Sioux Falls, Sanford isn't even listed as a top 5 of health care options in the area, and there really are only 2, Avera and Sanford.  Each year, when were given the report on how we did, actual healthcare for our patients is never even mentioned, just how much money we did or didn't make.  That's the focus.  On our strategic plans, there is nothing about improving the actual care we give patients, just expanding our research and footprint.  Sanford is no longer in the actual patient care business, if you listen to corporate leadership.  Last but not least, they mislead you on your benefits.  When it comes to PTO, they tell you start off with earning 7.1 hours per pay period, which sounds OK.  What they don't tell you is that you MUST use PTO hours on all holidays.  They don't pay you for holidays and they don't let you work them, unless you're in direct patient care.  They force you to take the day off and use your PTO hours, whether you want to or not.
